intro: Gnaphaliothamnus macdonaldii, commonly known as MacDonald's ghostflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is known for its small, pale yellow to white flowers. It has aromatic foliage that emits a distinctive scent, and its leaves are narrow and covered in fine hairs. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
